Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of Immune Loci Critical in Antigen Recognition
Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on the evolution of the adaptive immune system, which enables animals to respond powerfully and specifically to pathogens of many different types. A key feature of adaptive immunity is antigen recognition by two types of antigen receptors: antibodies (immunoglobulins, produced by B cells, and the source of humoral immunity), and T-cell receptors (TCR; involved in cellular immunity). Because of their extraordinary diversity, these receptors can bind to a wide range of biological molecules; receptor diversity is created by unique genetic mechanisms (somatic gene rearrangement and hypermutation) characteristic of the adaptive immune response. Previous work has shown that the oldest jawed vertebrates on earth, the cartilaginous fish (including sharks), have all of the basic molecular hardware of this system. However, some elements of the mammalian adaptive immune system - lymph nodes, bone marrow, and specialized lymphoid tissue such as germinal centers - are absent in sharks; sharks thus provide a relatively simple model to understand the most fundamental characteristics of adaptive immunity. Although T cells and B cells have been considered quite distinct in function, this laboratory discovered in shark cells an antigen receptor, NAR-TCR, that uses the same domain in both cellular (TCR) and humoral (antibody) immunity; it has also now documented multiple instances of shark T-cells with properties (e.g., immunoglobulin variable domains and somatic hypermutation) previously ascribed only to B-cells. Building on these findings, this project will reexamine the basic definition of vertebrate B and T cells by exploring the boundaries of the immunogenetic mechanisms available to each cell type. The unexpected plasticity of these boundaries offers provocative new perspectives on the evolution of the vertebrate immune system; it also suggests new possibilities for immune response manipulation in other vertebrates, including humans. Student research training from high school through graduate levels is integral to the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: One of the goals of this project was to investigate the organization of shark TCR loci allowing what we then termed trans-rearrangement with immunoglobulin variable genes. We discovered that immunoglobulin variable genes reside in the shark TCR αδ locus, thus trans- could be a misnomer. We found that these Ig-TCR chimaeras are expressed transcriptionally at a level close to canonical TCR, and by flow cytometry see cells expressing them in sharks young and old. These findings spawned studies into Ig/TCR locus organization and RAG activity in other vertebrates including bony fish and frog (interestingly, the ray-finned bony fishes may be the only major class of jawed vertebrates not to use the Ig-TCR antigen receptor chains). Another goal of the expiring award was to characterize somatic hypermuation at TCR loci. As described here and in a manuscript in preparation, we have painstakingly mapped enough of the TCR αδ locus to attribute TCR transcripts to germline variable genes and analyzed enough clones to study only unmistakable mutations within families of TCR with the same CDR3 rearrangement. This proof of TCRα SHM led to more questions of unheralded AID function, including a fruitful collaboration with Vaughn Smider’s group at Scripps on the “ultralong CDR3” immunoglobulin heavy chains of cattle, where we find extraordinary SHM at a new microdomain which made the cover of Cell. We have evidence that AID is capable of mini-deletions in these ultralong CDR3 encoding sequences that mechanistically result in what look like class-switch recombination at the DNA level.

Broader Impacts: All the while, weekly trips to A&M Consolidated High School keep us grounded as we work with Matt Young’s exceptional Advanced Biotechnology classes and host these young researchers in my lab. Although neither paradigm-shifting nor high impact science, Heather Weir’s publication of a high school research project written by a high school science student is a paper of which I am most proud. This project is in its last year and generated ten publications (so far) and completed one doctoral dissertation and one master’s thesis.
